title: 106_hr1556
content: The "Prevention of School Violence Act of 1999" emphasizes the importance of ensuring students' safety in schools. Despite schools being generally safe, recent violent incidents highlight the need for continued efforts to enhance school safety and create a conducive learning environment. There is a growing urgency to understand the root causes of student violence and implement effective prevention strategies. Establishment of National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence, known as the "National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence." Membership of the Commission. The National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence is composed of 11 members appointed by various officials, including the Speaker of the House, Minority Leader of the House, Majority Leader of the Senate, Minority Leader of the Senate, Secretary of Education, Attorney General, and Secretary of Health and Human Services. Appointing officials must consult with each other to ensure qualifications are met. Each appointee must meet specific qualifications. The National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence appoints 11 members with specific qualifications related to child and adolescent behavior, at-risk children, and school safety. The panel includes individuals recognized for their expertise in these fields, as well as a parent and a recent high school graduate from a school where a violent incident occurred. The panel appointed for the National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence includes professionals with expertise in issues related to violent and delinquent youth, juvenile justice, and the impact of media on children. Preference is given to those who are also parents. The members consult experts from education and the criminal justice field in carrying out their responsibilities. The National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence consults a wide range of experts and stakeholders, including professionals from education and the criminal justice field, behavioral scientists, school safety experts, school psychologists, organizations dealing with at-risk youth, public health officials, statisticians, criminologists, students, and parents. The National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence includes a diverse group of experts and stakeholders such as public health officials, statisticians, criminologists, students, and parents. The Commission elects a Chairman and Vice Chairperson, with a majority of members constituting a quorum for decision-making. Appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment, with provisions for delayed appointments. The National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence appoints members within 30 days. If not, appointments can be made by designated officials. Each member has one equal vote. Vacancies are filled as per original appointment method. Members are prohibited from receiving additional pay. The National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence appoints members within 30 days, with vacancies filled in the same manner. Members are prohibited from receiving additional pay, but may receive travel expenses. The initial meeting of the Commission must occur within 40 days of the Act's enactment. Members are prohibited from receiving additional pay, but may receive travel expenses. The initial meeting of the Commission must occur within 40 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. FUNCTIONS OF COMMISSION. The Commission will study school violence incidents, interviewing perpetrators, families, friends, and professionals for insights. Findings and recommendations will cover the extent and root causes of school violence, key factors, successful prevention approaches like early identification and conflict resolution. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress within 1 year, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for administrative and legislative action to prevent school violence. A majority vote is required for recommendations. The Commission's recommendations for administrative and legislative action to prevent school violence require a majority vote for adoption by the members present. The Commission has the power to make recommendations for preventing school violence, requiring a majority vote for adoption by the members present. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, adopt rules and regulations, and request information from federal agencies for the purpose of carrying out the Act. The Commission, upon request by the Chairperson, can access facilities, services, and personnel from Federal agencies to assist in carrying out its duties. The Commission is also allowed to use the United States mails and enter into contracts with various entities as provided in appropriation Acts. The Commission can enter into contracts with State agencies, private firms, institutions, and individuals for research purposes. The Chairperson has the power to appoint an Executive Director and additional staff as needed, without regard to certain provisions of the United States Code. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an Executive Director and additional staff at rates not exceeding the maximum rate for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission's expenses are limited to $650,000 and funds appropriated for this purpose can remain available until expended or up to one year after the Commission's termination. The Commission will cease to exist 60 days after submitting its final report as required by section 4(b).
